												The Call of Juarez series is one I'd definitely recommend giving a go. Every game in the series is distinct and has its own identity, which is something I really appreciate. I'll avoid going into too much detail about the rest here, but they're all a good time with individual strengths and weaknesses that form a satisfying whole.Unfortunately, the defining characteristic of game number three, The Cartel, is that it's an utter shambles. The classic Wild West setting of the previous games was ditched for a staggeringly uninspired modern-day Los Angeles/Mexico counterpart, which is exactly as appealing as it sounds (i.e. not at all). Likewise, the hole left by the entertaining and likeable cast of the first game and Bound in Blood (like legendary gunslinger Ray McCall) is filled with some of the flattest caricatures to ever spout tired one-liners. Once all the character and charm of Call of Juarez has been stripped away, what you're left with is a medicore first-person shooter that is an absolute chore in single-player and probably not much better in the new co-op mode. Solo players be warned: your AI partners are incompetent, and they will make no effort to hide it, though they will continually belittle your performance as you carry them for the game's entire duration.Lackluster AI, boring gunplay, dull visuals and an uninteresting plot combine for eight hours of unmitigated tedium. The only saving grace is the way the game ends, which could have been a pretty cool conclusion to a much better game, but is of course held back here by being part of The Cartel. In retrospect it's good that the series had one final outing after this, though The Cartel remains a testament to how quickly good games can go bad. It's almost worth playing just for that lesson, though I'd suggest you try any of the others over this rubbish.

												Even though I'm giving it a thumbs up, I have mixed feelings about this game. The Cartel is the worst game in the Call of Juarez series, but it does have a few features that other games in the series (and even many co-op FPS games in general) don't have and make this game unique and somehow enjoyable to play. I would recommend this, but only when it's heavily discounted and you've got one or two friends to play in co-op with.PROS+ Good campaign mode with an intriguing (and underrated) storyline and characters, 4 endings and amazing soundtrack.+ An "unusual" take on co-op approach+ Replayable: 3 playable characters each with their own objectives, roles and dialogues (e.g. talking with different characters on the cellphone). Playing the story once with one character, in fact, may lead to plot-holes.+ Varied levels with car chases, nightclub shooting, highways and more.CONS- Unfinished: the game got released when its development wasn't finished yet. It is technically horrible, with dull graphics, many bugs and audio issues. Expect frustrating moments.- The main menu and the first levels are dull (luckily the game gets slightly better and more interesting afterwards).- The gunplay, the driving and grenades.- No drop-in joining (players can only join your co-op match at the start of a level).The game as-is, is MOSTLY technically horrible, but if you can get past its technical issues and focus on everything else, you might enjoy it in co-op with one or two friends. If only Techland had more time to develop this it could have probably been a masterpiece; co-op mode is good and unique, the story is decent and has its moments, but the rest is heavily unpolished. Dead Island, which is made by the same devs, got released in the same year.Tip before you play: don't tell your friends what you're doing and what your character says in certain moments for the full experience!

												Call of Juarez is a western-themed FPS game series released by Ubisoft. The Cartel is the "odd one out" in this series as it is the only one taking place in a modern day setting instead of the good old Wild West. Interestingly, the concept works and it makes for a good - albeit somewhat mediocre - game that fans can feel free to pick up as it becomes, after all, an important part of the franchise.The game is best played cooperatively. For some reason the developer decided to pick not two (remember Bound In Blood?) but 3 protagonists. When playing alone they are controlled by the A.I but they are not exactly sharpshooters; however, the upside here is that you do not need to revive any of them.They all work for a different organisation serving their country - Ben is an LAPD cop (he wears a cowboy hat and his surname indicates he is the descendant of Ray McCall from the 1st game), Kim is from the FBI and Eddie represents the DEA. They are all after The Cartel and during gameplay each of them receives a phone call asking them to complete a secondary objective. This is pretty funny as with each player you are to pick up various things and the rest cannot know about it. If noticed, you lose the opportunity. These are all illegal activities (such as stealing money) as to a certain degree all of them are dirty.There are some driving sequences, too. One player drives while the rest do the shooting. The mechanics are similar to the one experienced in Dead Island (another Techland game series): it is pretty easy to navigate but the camera is positioned behind the dashboard so you do not exactly have the chance to change the view. There's also levelling up that unlocks newer and more powerful weapons throughout the game but it is pretty generic. Multiplayer is also available and while it does not offer anything new it is pretty entertaining. Like I said this is the odd one out in the series but it does not mean it is a bad game. At the time (2011) the Chrome engine already looked outdated and while there is a handful of cinematics the game's story is not exactly very original. Still, The Cartel is an entertaining game and if you liked Call of Juarez you might get fond of this, too. Just remember: beside McCall's character and the slow-mo shootouts and the available revolvers nothing really makes you remember its predecessors. Perhaps it's best to wait for a discount so as not to be disappointed very much.

YES! Except the pistols, so I just used the pistols the whole game, except during Concentration mode (slows down time and increases accuracy for a short period of time) that you get by killing people, and also used rifles and smg's during the car shootout and car chases, because pistol kind of suck in those situations. There are also pretty ugly bugs here and there and some glitches, but Techland just doesn't give a sh*it and instead of patching it up, they just decided to move on to another sh*tty project called Dead Island: Riptide, and that worked out pretty well, didn't it? Huh...Multiplayer is your standard rack up kills, get XP, new level, YAY! Here's a new ♥♥♥♥♥♥ weapon, have a blast!Noone plays it anymore btw, so if you want to get it, buy for the SP Campaign (with a bad story as well, pretty bad and nonsensical and uninteresting and many more bad adjectives) which is decently long (around 7 to 8 hours) and the collectibles are an interesting mechanic as well as they work like side missions and you kind of have to do it discretely so that the other 2 agents don't catch you. Just joking! It does NOT use GFWL, thankfully, but it does use UPlay, which is Ubisoft's DRM for their games, I haven't had any huge issues with this DRM, it's just annoying but I can live with it...it doesn't deserve more than a 4.5/10, save you 10 € for something better like Kane & Lynch 2 or Counter Strike: Global Offensive.I paid 4,99€ at a retail shop for this and honestly, I feel like it was worth it, but don't pay much more than that...

												Let's be straight. Call of Juarez: The Cartel is not really a good game. It take the wild west setting of the previous installments and brings them to the modern day. The game is buggy, it's incredibly linear, the gunplay is mediocre, the enemies are on the bullet sponge side and the AI is nonexistent as your partners are absolutely worthless at times. That said, I had an absolute blast playing CoJ: The Cartel. It is the video game equivalent of playing a B-Movie, and I love B-Movies. You see all the "twists & turns" in the story a mile away in a cliche ridden script filled with stereotypes and eye rolling dialogue,  But like a trainwreck I just couldn't take my eyes off of it. You play one of the individuals from different agencies (FBI, DEA & LAPD) put in a task agency meant to take down the Mendoza Cartel who is responsible for drugs, gun running, human trafficking, domestic terrorism blah blah blah and then off you go. I really liked the level variety. You from the Sequioa National Forest to the Streets of L.A. to Arizona and finally to Juarez, Mexico. All very nicely realized. Gameplay wise, you don't have much to do other than going from point A to point B while killing lots of dirtbags along the way. Sometimes you'll get a side mission but those pretty much consist of finding an item on the level somewhere. One escort mission where you are being chased through the streets of LA and up the freeway deserves special mention. An absolute blast. I also felt the voice acting was excellent. Like I said, CoJ: The Cartel is not really a good game but I enjoyed the hell out of it.  If you're looking for political correctness, mind blowing set pieces & a leap forward into the FPS genre look elsewhere. But if the positives I've mentioned are up your alley, well here you go. 7/10 from me.

Shoot, cover, rinse and repeat with the straight forward driving sections to mix up the gameplay a bit.If you stick with it to the end, you can see some design choices that carried over from the others in the series, which they attempted to improve upon, but ultimately ended up with mixed results.This game was clearly made for a co-op experience and it is strongly recommended to play it that way if at first you find it really hard to have fun.It is not a very good game, but it is also not a completely bad one either. If you give it a chance, it can grow on you. With its equal amount of shining and eye-rolling moments, it is an underrated title.

The Mexican Drug War, Juarez style.Call of Juarez: The Cartel, third installment into Techland's CoJ series, seems like the misfit child of the bunch.  It's not as good as Call of Juarez: Gunslinger; it's not a game to be taken seriously or to carry any real expectations for, whether you're a fan of this developer or not.  As action shooters go, it's definitely more of the same.  It did provide me a brief bit of fun & includes a potentially decent cooperative experience.The Dead Island series & Dying Light are by Techland too, so if you liked those you'll be at home with The Cartel, which looks and feels similar in a number of ways.  Level design, enemy AI, linearity of missions, visuals/art, side tasks involving item collection, gun aiming & handling, driving & playable characters with unique personalities & combat characteristics all felt familiar.  What you shouldn't expect much of in The Cartel is homage to the CoJ series itself, 'cuz there ain't much.  You do get to play as a modern day McCall, dual wield revolvers, take a brief jaunt through a familiar place & hear a schpeel from a guy who's obsessed with the treasure of Juarez.  None of that gives this a real connection to the rest of the series, however.  In my opinion it lacks the flair that makes the others entertaining.By 2011 standards The Cartel is decent, & I'd say by today's (2015) it's mediocre but worthy of purchase on the cheap.  I got it on sale and can't imagine anyone doing otherwise, by now.  It's a very brief campaign consisting of 15 missions; took me about 7 hours to finish on Medium difficulty, with the AI companions rather than real teammates.The AI teammates worked out well enough, although I regrettably didn't play it with anyone else & thus missed out on what looks like a fun three player co-op.  You can breach rooms together, provide covering fire allowing allies to advance & also engage in some friendly competition via the Secret Agenda feature (each law enforcement agent has an ulterior motive & they each mistrust each other, so you try to catch the other two red-handed while being sneaky & accomplishing your own hidden objective unnoticed).I tried doing some multiplayer action online but was unable to find anyone for the Cops vs. Criminals mode or the online campaign mode.This game is published by Ubisoft & requires their client, Uplay to run alongside Steam.There were some (sadly not too) farfetched news clip cutscenes and a lot of interagency bluster between the LAPD, FBI & DEA that I found entertaining.  The entire game is pretty much a sensationalized portrayal of the Mexican Drug War.  Each character & most of the dialogue was cliche.  I feel like I'm describing a Hollywood blockbuster film.  I'm not saying I wouldn't recommend Call of Juarez: The Cartel to anyone; it was okay.  It just doesn't merit recommendation unless you're looking for a quick bit of shoot-em-up action & don't have better alternatives - or if you're a big fan of this dev & just crave that experience.

												Call of Juarez®: The Cartel is the third game in the series. It is considered to be the worst Call of Juarez game, but is it realy that bad?I consider myself a fan of CoJ series. And I like western setting in general. So it was sad to hear that the third game of epic western shooters is actually not a western, because the action takes place in 2011 and the setting here is called...ugh, "Neo-Western". Well, whatever. I've read some reviews of this game before playing so I wasn't expecting much to begin with. But let's talk about it, there are good things and bad things, like in any other game.First thing, the story, the setting, the atmosphere and the soundtrack. Well, those are not half bad if you ask me. Well, the story is a mess actually, there are lots of uninteresting dialogs and complicated stuff in the mood "who betrays whom", actually the story here is much worse compared to all other CoJ games (even the Gunslinger). There are 3 playable protagonists, the police officer Ben McCall (a walking tribute to Ray McCall, not as Badass as the latter, but not half bad though), the DEA agent Eddie Guerra (for some reason he remonds me of Pierce from Saints Row series, probably because of those black and purple tones in clothes) and FBI agent Kim Evans (the girl with an attitude). Each of them has their own problems and "inner demons", but in the end I can tell that only Ben McCall is interesting enough as a character. Anyway, the characters don't trust each other, there is no bond between them so you won't like them too much anyway. The heroes must find and terminate the Mendoza Drug Cartel, who is presumably responsible for some kind of bombing in which several people died. They investigate deeper into the case and it turns out to be that the culprits are also their higher ups in FBI/DEA or whatever. Anyway there are many things in story that I didn't get fully and that's quite sad, when the plot is overweight in lots of uninteresting twists. I'd say the story is really poor, well, at least there are several endings.The graphics in the game are so-so. Not bad but not good either. They say the developers were testing the new engine, meh. The soundtrack is actually pretty good. There are many decent western-themed tracks that actually create a western-feel in the game. There will be some missions in western setting and you will even visit Juarez, so those levels come along nicely with the soundtrack. In terms of gameplay the game is so-so. You can play as one of three characters and the other two will accompany you as AI bots (or you can play online with other people, but I couldn't find any partner via internet, looks like nobody plays this game anymore, lel), each one is good with a different type of weapons: mister McCall is good with pistols and heavy machineguns, the lady is good with sniper rifles and Eddie Guerra is decent with SMGs at medium range. There is almost no recoil from guns and it was kinda hard for me to shoot enemies at times for some reason. I just don't feel the gun and the crosshair in this game (and I didn't have this problem with other CoJ games by the way). Oh and you won't ride horses in Cartel, but there will be some car chasing missions and they are actually pretty fun.There are some bugs in the game, like clipping issues and stucking in the walls, but nothing serious so far.VERDICT: CoJ The Cartel is indeed the worst game in CoJ series, but it still has good things in it. And most importantly it feels like CoJ game and has a western feeling. The chars are pretty boring though (and some of them are just replicas from other games, like ben mccall and Juan mendosa), the story is not captivating and the gameplay is iffy at times. But I would still recommend this game to those who like Call of Juarez series. I think it is worth a try, at least, besides it is not very long and you can complete it within 7-8 hours. My personal rating for this game will be 6/10.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												After playing - and liking - Gunslinger, I wanted to get into more of the Call of Juarez series that I missed. The Cartel was the natural next entry to try because other than Gunslinger (2013) it was the most recent (2011).It's awful.I can only imagine that ads for this game claimed it was "high-octane" or contained "explosive firefights" and while there is the occasional fun moment, for the most part it is a boring, bland affair.Despite some cool concepts and set pieces, the graphics are subpar, even given when it came out. The animations are choppy, textures low-res and flat. The skyboxes are particularly grainy, like they were JPG compressed.The sound is even worse, with horribly repetitive dialogue delivered by some of the worst voice acting I've ever heard in a game.The menus are especially painful because of a terrible font choice and the fact that the mouse speed there is not affected by the sensitivity setting. It crawls across the screen and turns anything you want to do in a menu into a belabored chore.And the story is a jumbled mess of cliches. Where a run-of-the-mill FPS normally shines when it falls flat in other areas is the gameplay. As you might expect, that's not the case here. The enemies are predictable and easy to outmaneuver even on the highest difficulty. The weapons and controls are very standard. And there are driving sections that are more frustrating and annoying than they have any right to be.Unlike all the other games in the series this one takes place in modern times instead of the Wild West. The only thing it has in common with a Call of Juarez game is the name and a concentration mode. It's like they were trying to boost sales on a project they knew would fail by randomly attaching it to this pre-existing franchise.So if you want to play a Call of Juarez game, you're better off with Gunslinger. If you want a better FPS from 2011, then go play Homefront.

												Glitchy, poorly paced, and with attrociously frustrating driving mechanics, this game really is the low point of the Call of Juarez series.I generally try not to hate on games too hard, but in this case, they completely threw the concept of interesting, identifiable, and compelling characters right out the window. One of the player characters, Guerra, seems like he's got a bit of a story behind him (DEA agent that's a compulsive gambler and selling drugs on the side to try to pay off his debt), but it's never really fleshed out. The female characters name eludes me because she was so one dimensional it wasn't even worth remembering who she was.The game starts out with you "meeting" all of these characters in a high speed car chase in which you have no earthly idea what you're doing or why you're shooting at these various cars. Get used to that feeling, because this game rarely stops to explain what the hell is going on. After that you're catapulted into a world of tracking down the leader of a drug cartel after a DEA building is bombed (the connection between the two is nebulous at best), and protecting a girl who is thought to have witnessed the bombing... and also one of the playable characters survived and witnessed the bombing but is somehow expendable enough to simply throw into a massive, violent war against drugs rather than being temporarily relieved of duty and examined by psychiatrists to handle the mental trauma. Also, he's suspected of being the bomber, so... send him out on police work? Sure.What follows is a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥attempt at making an action game that allows you to sling enough lead to supply a Chinese paint factory for a month while also tossing all of the rules of common sense straight out the window in favor of cheap "thrills". Oh, and the driving sequences... God save us all from the driving sequences... The driving mechanic is so poorly designed and implimented that it's far more frustrating than cool, and unfortunately you're almost ALWAYS the driver. And as for the guns, they all feel approximately the same, apart from different skins and rates of fire.The storyline is approximately 6.5 hours in length, but manages to feel like it's dragging on for an eternity (see GTA V for the opposite effect, where it lasts 40+ hours and still feels like it's not enough), having overstayed its welcome within the first 45 minutes.With all of these terrible features, there were a few redeeming qualities. Personally, I felt like the bullet time mechanic was well done and well integrated, the music was quite well directed to fit the situation, and I do like seeing games branching out and police games starting to trickle onto the market. I also feel like some of the voice acting was done competently, and the graphics were, for the time, moderately good.Unfortunately, in my opinion, the few things it did right weren't enough to save this honker, and so I give it a thumbs down. Buy it only if it goes on sale for $2 and you need something to waste a few hours with.

												Definitely not as bad as the majority of other reviewers make it out to be. This is just like Resident Evil 5; when you take it out of the series, you have a decent game. When you compare it to the other games in the series, yeah, it's a bad game. On its own, not so.However, is this game good? Is this game going to make you tremble with ecstacy? Is this game will the "the one"? Hell no.The only thing keeping this game together is its incredible story. You can take this game's plot and shoot a blockbuster Hollywood movie with it. It's extremely realistic, dark, and a very good reflection of the hellhole we call politics. It becomes so complex sometimes that you need to pause the game and get all the pieces together in your mind's eye.Soundtrack is well done. It suits the theme of the game and the environments you play in very well. It's not ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic, but it's definitely enhancing.Voice-over is brilliant. You can feel they paid attention to quality in that department.AI? Well, it's complicated. Sometimes they just get stuck and stare at you like some idiots. Some other time, you see them flanking you, moving from cover to cover and getting you at your most vulnerable moment. Your partners though, they are completely useless. Don't expeck anything big and you won't have a problem with them. Gameplay mechanics? Bad. It's just plain bad. Covers don't always work, the game glitches and bugs in some missions, forcing  you to load a checkpoint, grenades are useless, weapons don't differ from each other much, playing offline really detracts from the whole gaming experience, etc. One good thing is the "Secret Agenda" system. During most missions, someone important calls you a gives you a secret mission that you must complete without being seen by your partners. It's a breeze when playing offline, but I reckon it adds a lot of excitement on online playing sessions. A very refreshing idea. More games should try something like this.Worst thing? Sound effects. You fire a shotgun and it sounds like a tiny balloon just popped. You fire a friggin M60 and it sounds like an old man's fart. You shoot you Desert Eagle and it sounds like a kid is clapping his little hands together. It's downright terrible.Overall, would I recommend this game? If it's below 5 bucks, yeah. It just isn't worth 10 dollars.

												Call of Juarez: The Cartel (just "Cartel" from now on) is one of those shooters that was a product of the times, or even slightly behind the times, and tried to meld a Western motif onto "modern day" (early 2000's, after 9/11) US Mexican border. This is a "modern" shooter where instead of hunting for health packs, just hide for a little while to regenerate your health (theres' not even a health meter). However, there is no cover system. It's side-strafing all the way. The back story is the DEA office in LA got bombed, and the DOJ arranged for a DEA guy, an FBI girl, and a LAPD veteran to for an interagency task force to find out who did it, then one of the dead agent's daughter had a message from his dead father... So she's a witness... The trio each had their own agenda they try to accomplish without revealing to their two partners. As the investigation takes them from barrios of LA to border to desert to Mexican estates, they get to shoot their way through a TON of bad guys of various types, from simple gangbangers all the way up to mercenaries. And sometimes, they even have to deal with heavy enemy support... like gunships. To do that, you get your standard arsenal, from pistols and revolvers to SMGs, assault rifles, shotguns, and even light machine guns. However, you can only keep two pistols and one long gun. To make things simple, all pistols use the same ammo, and all rifles use the same ammo, even though in real life they use different calibers. And yes, you can dual-wield the single-hand weapons like pistols and light SMGs. It's fun to do so, as you'll have two triggers (mouse left and mouse tright) for separate guns. The "Concentration mode" (i.e. Matrix slo-mo) is back, where basically time slows down so you can kill bad guys by pumping them full of lead before they can react. There are also various "breach" scenarios where your team line up on the door and at the signal, bust in, and in slow-mo, shoot everybody that has a gun. (Yes, there are often civilians, and you get an award if you don't cause collateral damage by end of campaign). One of the factors that sets Cartel apart are the driving sequences... where you get to drive the car, dodging traffic, and if you're not driving, you can hang out the window and shoot at bad guys. If necesary, that is. There is a mission where you need to tail another car, not too close, not too far. (And don't run over civilians)  But often, you need to chase enemy vehicle while dodging things left and right, and sometimes, you just need to get away. Another thing that sets Cartel apart is the fact that this is a 3 player co-op shooter... In "single player" you play with two AI bots. if you have multiplayer set two buddies join you to shoot your way through bad guys. There's also competitive mode online. It's basically the same game instead of completely separate SP vs. MP map levels. As mentioned before, each member of the team has their own personal agenda, and often will get calls or reminders about where their ultimate loyalty lies, and have "secret agenda" on missions, as well as try to sneak some evidence, money, or such "found" on various parts of the mission. And they have to do so without being seen by their partners, making it tense. This is how the character gain "XP" for levels to unlock additional weapons,  in fact. So you have to explore a little. The story is actually better than the average shooter. There's no "foozle", just a lot of guys with guns, and each guy has their own motivation to "do the right thing", which may not be THE right thing. The hardware requirements are strange. I can play COJ: Gunslinger with no problem, but somehow Cartel felt slower. At least the bots know how to conduct themselves. All in all, COJ: The Cartel is a hard break from the "Western" roots of COJ. There are some tie-ins but ultimately it felt really weak. The shooters are not bad, and 15 levels ain't bad for co-op, but it's not exactly a shining sample of how shooters *should* be done. I applaud them of trying to break new ground, but the execution seems to lack that "must keep playing" feeling. It's recommended, but only if it's at bargain bin level prices.
